title: Dollar Rises to Two-Year High on Consumer Sentiment
summary: Investors have also turned to greenback as haven during global tensions. The U.S. dollar climbed to its highest closing level in more than two years as fresh data showed that consumer sentiment among Americans remained strong.

title: House Passes Bill Extending Civil Rights to Gay, Transgender People
summary: Equality Act, which bans discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity, is unlikely to pass in Senate. The House of Representatives passed a bill that would ban discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity, though it is unlikely to come up in the Republican-controlled Senate.

title: Government Bonds Rise on Trade Tensions
summary: Rise in Treasurys amid concerns about U.S.-China talks offset strong consumer report. U.S. government-bond prices ticked higher Friday as continuing trade tensions offset strong consumer-sentiment data.

title: Trump's Immigration Progress
summary: He admits the U.S. needs talent but he's still too stingy on visas.. President Trump campaigned in 2016 as an immigration restrictionist, and most of the time he still is. But this week he made his largest move to date toward a more welcoming view of legal immigration, albeit with some unfortunate contradictions.

title: Cuomo vs. New York
summary: The Governor cancels another natural gas pipeline.. Governor Andrew Cuomo proved again this week that the biggest threat to New York isn't Donald Trump, but progressive anti-growth policies. Witness his administration's permit rejection for a 23-mile natural gas pipeline connecting New York City and Long Island with Pennsylvania shale gas fields.

title: A Metals Tariff Reprieve
summary: Good news for steel consumers, but border taxes could be reimposed.. Trade policy is never a straight line with the Trump Administration, and Friday's agreement among the U.S., Mexico and Canada to lift steel and aluminum tariffs is a good example of two steps forward and one step back.

title: Pinterest Shares Fall Following Earnings Report
summary: Company beats analysts' revenue expectations, but falls short of the consensus net income view. Shares of Pinterest Inc. plunged in extended trading after the company posted a loss in its first quarterly report following its public-market debut and worried investors with its full-year outlook.

title: Fed's Harker Says He's Not in a Rush to Raise Rates
summary: Bank of Philadelphia president said he thinks borrowing costs are still below the neutral level that neither stimulates nor restricts growth. PHILADELPHIA-Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia President Patrick Harker said Friday he's not sure about the likely path of interest rates this year.

title: States' Abortion Curbs Put Supreme Court to the Test
summary: Will Roe v. Wade be overturned? It may be up to Chief Justice Roberts, Trump appointees. Sweeping state-level abortion restrictions present a direct test of whether the Supreme Court is willing to revisit Roe v. Wade, the landmark abortion-rights precedent that has spurred deep divisions for nearly 50 years.

title: U.S. Seeks to Resolve Other Trade Disputes Amid China Impasse
summary: Trump administration postpones auto tariffs and agrees to end metals levies on Canada and Mexico. WASHINGTON-With U.S.-China trade talks at an impasse, President Trump moved Friday to tackle festering trade disputes with U.S. allies and North American neighbors.

title: Trump Administration Says It Is Waiting 'by the Phone' for Iran to Call
summary: Hostile rhetoric eases, but officials say U.S.-Iran tensions remain. WASHINGTON-Tensions between the U.S. and Iran appeared to ease on Friday after two weeks of crisis, as the White House tamped down talk of conflict and renewed a conditional offer to Tehran of diplomatic negotiations.

title: U.S. Reaches Deal With Canada, Mexico to End Steel and Aluminum Tariffs
summary: The duties have threatened congressional passage of President Trump's revamped trade pact with the two nations. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration reached agreements with Canada and Mexico to end U.S.-imposed tariffs on steel and aluminum imports and unwind retaliatory measures, removing a major barrier to the three countries' new trade pact.

title: Amazon Invests in U.K. Food-Delivery Startup Deliveroo
summary: The British meal-delivery service said it raised $575 million in a recent funding round, led by the online retail giant. LONDON- Amazon.com Inc. is investing in British food-delivery company Deliveroo, becoming one of the startup's biggest investors and signaling a continued interest in a sector that has confounded the e-commerce giant and others.

title: Trump's Border Wall Faces First Court Challenge
summary: Administration lawyers square off against Democratic-led states and others who say president can't act without congressional authorization. OAKLAND, Calif.-President Trump's push to pay for construction of a southern border wall without congressional authorization faced its first court test on Friday, as administration lawyers squared off against Democratic-led states, environmental groups and border communities seeking to halt the White House's plans.

title: Stocks Lose Steam, Close Lower for the Week
summary: Dow industrials log a fourth straight week of declines. The Dow Jones Industrial Average slumped for a fourth consecutive week Friday, with some analysts saying stocks could face continued pressure as the trade dispute between Washington and Beijing drags on.

title: Trian Nears Settlement With Legg Mason, Could Get Up to Four Board Seats
summary: Activist hedge fund pressed the money manager to cut costs and improve margins-and said a proxy fight was possible. Money manager Legg Mason Inc. is nearing a settlement with Trian Fund Management LP that would give the activist hedge fund three or four seats on its board and avoid a proxy fight, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Trump Administration Considers Flying Migrants Across U.S. to Relieve Border Crowding
summary: Local officials voice alarm as federal government considers expanding chartered jet program. The Trump administration may begin flying asylum-seeking families at the southern U.S. border across the country to have their initial claims processed, a Customs and Border Protection official said Friday.

summary: Wynn Resorts and MGM said they have had conversations in recent weeks about a potential sale of the Everett, Mass., project. Wynn Resorts Ltd. and MGM Resorts International are in talks for Wynn to sell its Boston-area casino project to rival MGM.

summary: Most Popular News. The mechanics of chief-executive pay have grown ever more complex, but the rules remain simple: Strong performers get a raise. So do most of the rest.

summary: Starbucks's main rival in China begins trading on Nasdaq. Shares of Luckin Coffee Inc. jumped 20% Friday in their trading debut on the Nasdaq Stock Market as the Chinese coffee chain takes on Starbucks Corp.

title: Report Says Ohio State Doctor Sexually Abused 177 Male Students
summary: School officials allegedly were aware, but did little to stop now-deceased doctor. COLUMBUS, Ohio-An Ohio State University team doctor sexually abused at least 177 male students over nearly two decades, and numerous university officials were aware but did little to stop him, according to a report released by the school Friday.

title: U.S. Blacklists Mexican Judge, Former Governor Over Alleged Ties to Drug Cartels
summary: Treasury Department says a magistrate judge and a former Mexican state governor received bribes. The U.S. imposed sanctions on a current and a former Mexican official who are alleged to have helped purported drug traffickers.

title: Singapore's GIC Takes Stake in WaterBridge at $2.8 Billion Valuation
summary: WaterBridge Resources deal highlights rising importance of businesses that handle wastewater from fracking. Singapore sovereign-wealth fund GIC has bought a stake in WaterBridge Resources LLC in a deal that values the Houston-based handler of oil-drilling wastewater at $2.8 billion including debt.

title: Hewlett Packard Enterprise to Buy Supercomputer Builder Cray
summary: Acquisition for $1.44 billion is part of business-technology giant's efforts to invest in high-performance computing. Hewlett Packard Enterprise Co. agreed to buy supercomputer maker Cray Inc. in a $1.44 billion deal as part of its efforts to invest in high-performance computing.

title: Reclaiming History From Howard Zinn
summary: The left's portrait of America's past has triumphed thanks to the abdication of serious historians. Wilfred M. McClay offers an antidote.. If you're old enough to remember the Soviet Union, you've probably wondered why so many young people today seem attracted to socialism. One influence is Howard Zinn, who published "A People's History of the United States" in 1980, the year before the first millennials were born.

title: If U.S.-China Marriage Can Be Saved, Huawei Is the Key
summary: Beijing needs something to gain. Access to the U.S. market for its tech champ heals many wounds.. A lot else was going on when the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act of 1930 hit a world economy laboring under declining nominal spending thanks to an ill-starred monetary contraction. President Trump's tariffs on China will have consequences but not as dramatic. They are a source of cash for the Treasury-yes. They are not a source of "wealth" for the country. Tariffs are a tax on consumers, but the U.S. market for cheap goods is highly competitive, so producers are likely to relocate production from China to countries not covered by the tariffs.

title: The Myth of 'Wage Stagnation'
summary: Usual measures of inflation don't count the benefits of better products and more consumer choice.. Perhaps the most common indictment of America's legendary prosperity is wage stagnation. Bureau of Labor Statistics data show that average hourly earnings of production and nonsupervisory employees peaked in October 1972 at $23.26 (in 2019 dollars) and were at that same level in March 2019. But do these numbers remotely describe the life you have lived over the past 45 years, or square in any way with numerous official measures of changes in what Americans actually own and consume? In short, should you believe your eyes or government data?

title: Trump's Trade War With China Is Taxing Missouri Farmers
summary: My patriotic friends and neighbors support the president, but they've given about all they can.. Tarkio, Mo.

title: Stressed-Out American Parents Could Learn a Lesson From India
summary: The country is chaotic and underdeveloped, but moms and dads are sensitive, empathic and attentive.. As I waited to board my flight from New York to India, I saw a father and his toddler. The boy was active, obviously tired and overwhelmed. This father started to scream and threaten his son with physical punishment. It took considerable self-control for me not to go over to the father and instruct him on everything he was doing wrong.

title: Mnuchin Defies Subpoena for Trump Tax Returns
summary: Democrats now face choice about how to enforce their demand for six years of tax records. WASHINGTON-Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and IRS Commissioner Charles Rettig defied congressional subpoenas by missing a Friday deadline to hand over six years of President Trump's tax returns and audit records.

title: 'Endeavour' Review: The Floating Laboratory
summary: She was outﬁtted with 22 guns and cutting-edge instruments: sextants, azimuth compasses and telescopes to observe the 1769 transit of Venus.. Long after carrying Capt. James Cook to the far side of the world, the naval vessel HM Bark Endeavour continues to inspire adulation, most of all in Great Britain, Australia and New Zealand. In 1768, joined by nearly 100 crewmembers in addition to the prominent naturalist Joseph Banks, Cook, just shy of 40 years old, embarked from London for the South Seas in the first of three storied expeditions. Following a short, inhospitable stay in Rio de Janeiro, he spent months exploring Tahiti and mapping the coastlines of New Zealand's North and South islands. Besides returning with innumerable botanical specimens and a small menagerie of animals, Cook became the first European explorer to chart the eastern coast of Australia, a place he claimed for Britain upon going ashore at Botany Bay near the present site of Sydney.

title: Notable & Quotable: 'Unreliable' News Sites
summary: 'We are removing this unreliable sites list until we are able to provide our audience a more consistent and rigorous set of criteria.'. A "Letter From the Editor" by Barbara Allen, published on the Poynter Institute website, May 2:

title: Science Fiction: The New Off-World Economy
summary: Space exploration isn't just romance; it's not even just to keep the human species from having all its eggs in one basket. It's also there, Daniel Suarez suggest, to save our economies from the day the debt-bubble bursts.. Ever sinceRobert Heinlein published "The Man Who Sold the Moon," back in 1950, sci-fi has held to two tenets. First, space exploration is bound to be made commercial: The romance of exploration alone isn't enough. Second, governments are the wrong kind of institution for space anyway. They're too risk-averse, too penny-pinching, and-as famously pointed out by Richard Feynman after the Challenger shuttle disaster-too reliant on managers, not engineers.

title: CBS Floated Offer of About $5 Billion for Pay-TV Channel Starz
summary: Discussions with Lions Gate come as CBS and sister company Viacom are again expected to consider a merger. CBS Corp. has had talks with Lions Gate Entertainment Corp. about acquiring its pay-TV channel Starz, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: 'How Shostakovich Changed My Mind' Review: Music and Madness
summary: How a work of music can save the lives and minds of those who play and hear it.. In August 1942, with emaciated corpses littering the streets and German guns booming all night long, Joseph Stalin decided that what Leningrad needed most was to hear the seventh symphony of Dmitri Shostakovich. The thunderous work had been premiered a few months before in Kubyshev, a city in Russia's interior to which the composer had been evacuated. The symphony had already been heard in Britain and the U.S. in broadcast performances conducted by Henry Wood and Arturo Toscanini. Bringing it to Leningrad under German siege would be both an act of defiance and a triumph of propaganda.

title: Barr Says Review of Russia Probe Could Spark Rule Changes
summary: 'Government power was used to spy on American citizens,' Barr says. SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador-Attorney General William Barr said his review of the origins of the Russia investigation is focused on U.S. intelligence gathering before the Federal Bureau of Investigation opened its formal inquiry in July 2016 and could lead to rule changes for counterintelligence investigations of political campaigns.

title: U.S.-China Talks Ignore Global Trade Rules
summary: The whole point of international trade law is that one country should not have the right to define what constitutes trade cheating.. Your May 11 editorial "The China Trade Impasse" omits an important word and value that should be central to America's trade fight with China: law. I refer to international trade law as codified in the rules of the World Trade Organization, which were co-authored and championed by previous U.S. administrations.

title: There's Nothing to 'Nationalize' in 5G Radio
summary: There is no singular "next-generation wireless network" to be seized by the government.. Mene Ukueberuwa's otherwise fine interview on 5G was marred by his casual repetition of a misleading trope-that the Trump administration once floated the idea of "nationalizing America's next-generation wireless network" ("The Yeoman Work Behind 5G Wizardry," The Weekend Interview with Dino Flore, May 11).

title: Dear Graduates: Risk and Responsibility Get You Far
summary: That's why it's called commencement: It's the beginning.. We have written dozens of books denigrating the administrators, the faculty, the students and everything else associated with higher education. And in one column, Jason Gay sets it all in context ("Class of 2019: The Secret No One Will Tell You," Exchange, May 11). He gets the chaos, the immaturity, the need to find fault with anything in the past, and the essence of a liberal-arts education: risk. Major in something you love and have passion for, make sure you've got enough technology, and then jump into the void. That's why it's called commencement: It's the beginning. We educate for risk; that's what makes us exceptional and why the rest of the world can't replicate what we do in those four years of college.

title: Uber's Capitalist Innovation Battles Union Obstruction
summary: Unions have the responsibility to increase their employees' value, but instead they tend to obstruct.. Your editorial is right to point out that Uber is classic capitalism at work ("Uber's Risk Is Politics," May 10). Unions have the responsibility to increase their employees' value, but instead they tend to obstruct technological progress like Uber's innovations.

title: Rotten Regimes Don't Crack Until the Cash Is Cut Off
summary: Cuba receives roughly $3.5 billion a year in foreign remittances, mostly from Cubans living in the U.S.. Mary Anastasia O'Grady's column "How to Liberate Venezuela" makes a compelling argument for putting pressure on Havana (The Americas, May 13). Cuba receives roughly $3.5 billion a year in foreign remittances, mostly from Cubans living in the U.S. President Obama also opened up certain forms of travel to Cuba and allowed cruise ships to call on Cuban ports, thus giving Cuba access to more U.S. dollars.

title: Google to Refund Advertisers After Suit Over Fraud Scheme

title: Incoming Chicago Mayor to Strip Key Powers of City Aldermen
summary: Former prosecutor Lori Lightfoot, who will be sworn in Monday, aims to cut corruption. title: Missouri House Passes Bill Banning Abortion at 8 Weeks

title: Remembering I.M. Pei: Farewell to a Modernist Master
summary: The architect, who died Thursday, was able to bridge contrary tendencies in the field, creating gorgeous yet unshowy buildings around the world.. No star was less starlike than I.M. Pei, the gentle, self-effacing Chinese-American architect who died Thursday at age 102. Mr. Pei was the last of the great classical modernists, his work notable for its elegant detail, sculptural sensibility and, above all, its consummate sense of restraint. These qualities are conspicuous in his Louvre Pyramid (1989), the structure with which he will forever be associated.

title: No More Dull Drapes: An A-to-Z Guide to Window Treatments
summary: Shades, drapes, swags, valances-where do you start? Designers share all the advice you need to achieve dapper window decorating, including tips on new technologies. MY WINDOW treatments give me-to use the patois of the internet-the Sads. The thick, faux-wood blinds evoke sidewalk grates when they're open and an armadillo's flinty hide when shut. They came with the midcentury house my husband and I purchased last year in suburban Denver and, on the long to-do list I've been working through, replacing them ranks pretty much last. Only one thing softens my shame: We're clearly not the only folks who don't see any treat in window treatments.

title: The Global Crisis of Democracy
summary: As China and Russia attack free governments and push strongman rule, the U.S. has gone silent-and a new tide of authoritarianism is gathering.. There is nothing inevitable about the expansion of democracy. Among countries with populations above one million, there were only 11 democracies in 1900, 20 in 1920 and 29 in 1974. Only for the past quarter of a century has democracy been the world's predominant form of government. By 1993, the number of democracies had exploded to 77-representing, for the first time in history, a majority of countries with at least one million people. By 2006, the number of democracies had ticked up to 86.

title: Advertisers Pack Into U.K. 'Game of Thrones' Finale

title: Christopher Abbott's Star-Making Vehicle
summary: The actor, who has worked consistently for over a decade, gets his first mainstream lead TV role in Hulu's Catch-22. It's not that Christopher Abbott has never been a lead before. He earned glowing reviews for his performances in James White and It Comes At Night. And he stars in Hulu's Catch-22, an adaptation of Joseph Heller's bestselling war novel, which premieres today. But his career has largely been defined by his strong supporting roles (Martha Marcy May Marlene; Whiskey Tango Foxtrot; First Man); as a result, the 33-year-old actor still enjoys a certain degree of anonymity, which is just fine by him. "It hasn't hit me that hard, at least in terms of what I've heard," he says. "Sometimes people recognize me, but usually they don't know what from. And I live in New York-it's never that big of a deal."

title: 'Dead-Cat Bounce': A Morbid Metaphor for a Brief Market Rally
summary: A volatile week for stocks has brought back a bizarre feline term. It's been a volatile week for the stock markets. But since then, stocks have climbed, offsetting the earlier losses.

title: When Turkey Destroyed Its Christians
summary: From 1894 to 1924, a staggered campaign of genocide targeted not just the region's Armenians but its Greek and Assyrian communities as well​. Between 1894 and 1924, the number of Christians in Asia Minor fell from some 3-4 million to just tens of thousands-from 20% of the area's population to under 2%. Turkey has long attributed this decline to wars and the general chaos of the period, which claimed many Muslim lives as well. But the descendants of Turkey's Christians, many of them dispersed around the world since the 1920s, maintain that the Turks murdered about half of their forebears and expelled the rest.

title: SUVs Use More Gas, but Fitting More People Changes the Equation

title: Mysteries: Silvery Canines and Surgical Scalpels
summary: In his first novel in 13 years, Thomas Harris has created a grotesque new villain to rival his iconic fava-bean-savoring Hannibal Lecter.. In the water-logged underground chamber of an empty Miami Beach mansion once owned by drug lord Pablo Escobar sits a booby-trapped steel safe holding some $25 million of gold. This semi-buried treasure is the urgent focus of two separate gangs of thieves in Thomas Harris's "Cari Mora" (Grand Central, 311 pages, $29), the author's first book in 13 years.

title: Kathleen Eisbrenner Helped Make Natural Gas a Globally Traded Fuel
summary: Entrepreneur advanced technology to allow imports at ports without costly onshore terminals. Kathleen Eisbrenner, a rare female entrepreneur in the energy industry, helped turn natural gas into a globally traded fuel.

title: Michel Roux Gave Snob Appeal to Vodka With Absolut Ads
summary: French-born marketer courted gay drinkers and enlisted Warhol to transform obscure brand into a sensation. Michel Roux, a Frenchman who got his start in the hotel industry and once worked as a dishwasher, pulled off the remarkable feat of endowing vodka with snob appeal.

title: Five Best: Sonia Purnell on the Allied Resistance
summary: The author, most recently, of 'A Woman of No Importance: The Untold Story of the American Spy Who Helped Win World War II' recommends works about the battles within occupied European countries.. By Denis Rake (1968)

title: Children's Books: High School as High Art
summary: A cult-classic film redone in the blank-verse style of the Bard.. Creative ideas have a wonderful way of traveling, twisting, fizzing, disappearing from view and then popping up again in unexpected forms. Consider this example: In Elizabethan England, William Shakespeare wrote plays in iambic pentameter. In the United States in 2002, Rosalind Wiseman published "Queen Bees & Wannabes," a self-help book for girls navigating high-school factions. Two years later, Tina Fey adapted Ms. Wiseman's book to make the cult-favorite movie "Mean Girls." And now Ian Doescher has mashed all these pieces together for "William Shakespeare's Much Ado About Mean Girls" (Quirk, 176 pages, $12.99), a hilarious closet drama composed in the style of the Bard. What Mr. Doescher in his prologue slyly calls a "fey story" recasts each scene of the film as it might have been staged at the Globe Theatre, with pratfalls, murmured asides, and entrances and exeunts galore. As devotees of "Mean Girls" can tell you, the story follows 16-year-old Cady Heron, hitherto homeschooled by her zoologist parents in Africa, as she enters the bewildering hierarchies of junior year at North Shore High in Evanston, Ill. Or, as Cady puts it: "Farewell said I to Afric and its plains, / And bid hello to high school and its pains."

title: 2020 GR Supra: Toyota's New Bid to Overcome Banality
summary: Back after a roughly 20-year hiatus, Toyota's sporty GR Supra is designed to reinvigorate the brand's street cred. Dan Neil takes it out on the track.. TO DISPENSE WITH the boring details first: The 2020 Toyota GR Supra (front-engine, rear-drive two-seat berlinetta) emerges out of a joint project between Toyota and BMW . Most of the heavy bits are the same or quite similar to those of the new BMW Z4, including its 3.0-liter, turbo inline-six and the eight-speed ZF transmission. Both are built at Magna Steyr's campus in Austria, where they really know how to knock them together. I'd be unreasonably proud of owning either.

title: 'The Impeachers' Review: No One Said It Would Be Easy
summary: No president deserved removal more than Andrew Johnson. He advocated racism, fought Reconstruction and refused to enforce federal laws. He also survived by one vote.. In 1865, Andrew Johnson ascended to the presidency in the aftermath of Abraham Lincoln's assassination and embarked on a perverse campaign to roll back the Union's achievements during the Civil War. Racist mobs marauded unchecked through the South, killing African-Americans. Factions debated the terms of readmission for states that had seceded. Basic issues about citizenship, the right to vote and the direction of the country were up for grabs. Amid this turmoil, Johnson articulated a crabbed and unworkable vision for the future: "This is a country for white men," he declared, "and, by God, as long as I am president it shall be a government for white men."

title: Enjoy Outer Space! I'll Stay on Earth.
summary: In Jeff Bezos's vision of an otherworldly future, there's no word on the laundry situation.. Are we really all going to go live in outer space? Budding space Wonka Jeff Bezos had a big event last week to say it's coming, that his rocket company Blue Origin will help make it possible, but-not to sound like an intergalactic wet blanket-I'm on the fence about abandoning Earth, and schlepping off to the stars.

title: 'Henrik Ibsen: The Man and the Mask' Review: Riddles of the Sphinx
summary: How did this gruff, taciturn, intensely private man pick up the habit of writing masterpieces?. He's seen as a, sometimes as the, father of modern drama. But a look at Henrik Ibsen's life reveals an existence surprisingly distant from our own. It's hard to say which stage of postmodernism we've currently attained. (Are we post-postmodernists? Post-post-post?) Wherever we are, modernism's forebears often stand at some remove from us. Today the Norwegian autodidact who reconfigured Western theater in the mid- and late 19th century appears at once larger than life and blurredly remote.

title: 'Socrates in Love' Review: A Vigorous, Brilliant Young Man
summary: Socrates was eccentric and famously ugly. But in youth he had been an active soldier, celebrated dancer and avid lover.. If there is one philosophical nugget most people know by heart, it is "The unexamined life is not worth living." Socrates, who coined the phrase, is often called the founder of Western philosophy, his name the byword for wisdom, in a dead heat with Confucius. Yet the life of Socrates himself has remained largely unexamined.

title: Fiction: Tales of History and Imagination
summary: Novels about Harriet Tubman, a crusading Southern journalist and a teenage Gottfried Leibniz.. 'The most preposterous things in this narrative are true," writes Roxana Robinson in an endnote to "Dawson's Fall" (Sarah Crichton/FSG, 332 pages, $27), her potent amalgam of fiction, genealogy and archival transcripts. Ms. Robinson's central character, the newspaperman Francis Dawson, is also her great-grandfather, and by envisioning his life and death she conjures the conditions of post-Reconstruction South Carolina, a place defined by its "twinned tendencies toward violence: one from seven hundred years of savage border fighting, and one from two hundred years of that peculiar institution, slavery."

title: 'After the Party' Review: The Wrong Sort of People
summary: The 1930s heyday of British fascism has been well documented, but Cressida Connolly's novel makes the chumminess of Oswald Mosley and his followers seem freshly chilling.. Cressida Connolly's flawless new novel "After the Party," for all its darkness, seems suffused with the "soft, buttery" light of an English summer afternoon. Here fruit ripens in walled gardens, women stroll on pliant lawns and roses scent the air. But in June of 1938, infernal shadows lengthen. The world is facing war and in drowsy Sussex, as elsewhere, homegrown fascists have been galvanized by Oswald Mosley, the real-life founder of the British Union of Fascists party. "There was something tawny, a bird-of-prey glint," one character observes of "the Leader" when he visits her village, "almost as if he were a military official surveying the troops." Or a philanderer, which Mosley notoriously was, eyeing his next female conquest, which Phyllis Forrester decidedly is not. The youngest and mildest of three privileged sisters-they vaguely resemble the Mitford girls, one of whom became Mosley's second wife-Phyllis is "used to not choosing for herself" in matters of marriage, motherhood or, indeed, politics. But she knows her own strength. "People tended to tell me things," she says, reflecting on secrets closely held. "I think they thought I was a safe bet, not because they were so interested in me, but because they were so interested in themselves." Phyllis's steady gaze takes in everything: the countryside she loves, the social class she inhabits and the family around which the novel revolves. The family that will betray her to her own government.

title: Book Review: Why Birders Flock Together
summary: In the age of Facebook, Instagram and 24-hour nest-cams, birding has become a truly communal endeavor.. I began birding in 1994. Not birdwatching-birding. At that time there was still a debate about what you called it. "Birdwatching" sounded passive ("What are the birds up to today?"), more in tune with Keats's notion of negative capability, of "being in uncertainties, mysteries, doubts." "Birding," meanwhile, was active, out-there, with a premium on the swift identification of species and long lists of "gets." This was a false dichotomy, of course-all birders deal with uncertainties, and most keep (or once kept) lists. But the elision of bird-birder-birding somehow touched the beyond, and birding is now the word of choice. In the 25 years since I began doing it, however, the thing has changed utterly.

title: Taiwan Approves Same-Sex Marriage in First for Asia
summary: It comes months after voters expressed opposition to gay marriage in a referendum. Taiwan's legislature approved Asia's first same-sex marriage law, reinforcing the island's reputation as a tolerant democracy despite a turbulent public debate that exposed social divisions about gay rights.

title: Best Selling Books Week Ended May 11
summary: With data from NPD BookScan. NPD BookScan gathers point-of-sale book data from more than 16,000 locations across the U.S., representing about 85% of the nation's book sales. Print-book data providers include all major booksellers, web retailers and food stores. E-book data providers include all major e-book retailers. Free e-books and those selling for less than 99 cents are excluded from the ebook lists. The fiction and nonfiction combined lists include aggregated sales for all book formats (except audio books, bundles, boxed sets and foreign language editions) and feature a combination of adult, young adult and juvenile titles. The hardcover fiction and nonfiction lists also encompass a mix of adult, young adult and juvenile titles while the business list features only adult hardcover titles. Refer questions to Teresa.Vozzo@wsj.com.

title: Polo Shirts Are Boring: Try This Bond-Approved Alternative
summary: This summer, designers are invoking 007 with the terrycloth shirt. Wear one and they'll never see you sweat. THINK THAT ALL things terry-cloth should be relegated to the bathroom towel rack? Tell that to Sean Connery, aka James Bond, who sported a fuzzy playsuit (yes, a playsuit) in 1964's classic film "Goldfinger." Granted, 007 was en route to a swimming pool, but he cut a surprisingly pulled-together figure in his collared, sky-blue, short-shorted one-piece. First popularized as clothing in the 1960s and '70s, terry was worn in the form of polos and leisure suits by groovy suburban teens and their fathers. This spring, the cotton looped fabric has looped back into fashion.

title: U.S. Farmers Brace for Aid Package Some Fear Will Fall Short
summary: The failure of Beijing and Washington to settle differences further clouds the outlook for farmers already hit by floods and bad weather. Stalled trade talks between Beijing and Washington are exacerbating a slump in the U.S. Farm Belt, and many farmers don't believe an aid package being assembled by the Trump administration will be enough to compensate for the economic damage.

title: Surprises Made of Porcelain and Gold
summary: The artist Edmund de Waal transforms the Frick Collection. It isn't hard to find porcelain, gold or marble in Manhattan's Frick Collection-in fact, given how prominently they figured in the collecting tastes of its founder, steel magnate Henry Clay Frick (1849-1919), it would be hard to avoid them. But it is rare to encounter these luxurious materials in the forms they take in "Elective Affinities: Edmund de Waal at The Frick Collection."

summary: Airstrike in Yemen, Mass in St. Peter's Basilica, living in boats in the San Francisco Bay area and more. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Millennial Home Buyers Might Never Come Knocking
summary: The tepid U.S. housing market is still waiting for a buying surge from the generation that entered the workforce during the recession. It may never come.. More than a decade has passed since the financial crisis hit, yet the housing market remains in a deep funk. Fear not: A wave of millennial buyers is about to hit the scene.

title: Stocks to Watch: Deere, Cray, Hewlett Packard Enterprise, Baidu
summary: Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Friday's session. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Friday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours; premarket trading is specified separately.

title: Michael Lewis Makes Boring Stuff Interesting
summary: The writer's new podcast 'Against the Rules' asks what has happened to fairness in the U.S.. Michael Lewis doesn't really need this gig. His new podcast, "Against the Rules," doesn't pay anything close to his book-writing day job. It's unlikely to turn into a movie. Plus, the podcast's subject is pretty abstract: Who are the referees in our society? Who determines what is fair and even what is true? Is our whole system rigged from stem to stern, as everyone from President Donald Trump to sports fans to the Black Lives Matter movement insists?

title: Russia's Covert Tactics Aim to Alienate Ukraine's Western Neighbors
summary: Vandalized Hungarian center in Ukraine is among examples of Kremlin's efforts to inflame tensions between Kiev and its EU allies. Russia's efforts to keep Ukraine in its orbit have included invasions, targeted assassinations and economic coercion. Less prominently, Moscow has directed a clandestine campaign of vandalism and hate crimes aimed at spoiling Ukraine's relations with its western neighbors, Ukrainian and European officials say.

title: A Majority of Nissan's New Board Will Be Independent Directors
summary: Auto maker seeks to add outside oversight after governance problems the company blamed on former Chairman Carlos Ghosn. YOKOHAMA, Japan- Nissan Motor Co. announced a new slate of board directors, aiming to add outside oversight of management decisions after governance problems the company blamed on former Chairman Carlos Ghosn.

title: Nvidia's Cloud Still a Bit Thick
summary: Chip maker's prospects hinge on data center spending recovery, which it won't predict. Nvidia sees its business recovering this year, though the chip maker seems unwilling to bet on it.

title: Ariana Grande's Secret Weapon Is Director Hannah Lux Davis
summary: How the director of "thank u, next" and "7 rings" went from on-set makeup artist to one of the most in-demand music video directors in the industry. Director Hannah Lux Davis's jaw fell open when she was given a Tiffany engagement ring while on set in December. Although the 32-year-old director had married producer Brandon Bonfiglio just a few months before, this sparkler was a sisterly gift from the subject of that day's shoot: pop star Ariana Grande. The ring in question was the 8th Tiffany ring Grande had purchased. According to the singer's much-told story, the other seven were bought during a champagne-fueled shopping trip with her closest musical collaborators. The extravagance was the impetus for her chart-topping single "7 rings." Despite Davis's shocked reaction, which nearly 5 million people have watched in a behind-the-scenes featurette on YouTube, she says she was trying to keep it professional around her crew.

title: 5 See-Through High Heels to Clear Things Up
summary: PVC or Lucite accents on a black high-heeled show are a must for summer-how to give your wardrobe the all-clear. The sculptural wedge heel and lace-up detail make these a statement pair. $1,190, Dior boutiques nationwide.

title: It's All in the Cards for Top Baseball Stars
summary: Demand for collectibles of rising prospects is outpacing the number of collectors willing to sell. With the stock market taking some sharp swings in recent days, investors may want to turn to the baseball card market, where demand for the cards of hot prospects is outpacing the number of collectors willing to sell. Even the cards of slumping sluggers are holding their value because, just like in fantasy baseball, no one wants to sell low.

title: Foreign Cyberattackers Face Sanctions in EU
summary: Travel bans and asset freezes face hackers who target the bloc from abroad. European governments armed themselves with a new tool against cyberattackers, adopting a sanctions regime to allow them to penalize foreign individuals and entities as western countries seek fresh ways of deterring large-scale hacking of their computer networks.

title: Trade Battle Poses Risks for Junk-Loan Machinery
summary: Recent escalation of U.S.-China trade tensions is threatening to cut short nascent recovery in the market for collateralized loan obligations. The recent escalation of U.S.-China trade tensions is threatening to cut short a nascent recovery in the market for collateralized loan obligations, a critical piece of the machinery that provides funds to businesses with low credit ratings.

title: The Unfulfilled Promise of DNA Testing
summary: Resume Subscription. Hillary Savoie wanted clear answers. Instead, the genetic testing results for her 4-year-old daughter, Esmé, sent her reeling.

title: Good News: Investors Have Been Nervous All Year
summary: If someone actually starts wanting to buy stocks, the equity rally could find a second wind. If the top of the market is a point of peak optimism, then this month is an unlikely candidate. Investors were more nervous than they appeared even before the latest worries about U.S.-China trade negotiations.

title: In Vermont, Small Colleges Are Closing
summary: Three schools will hold their final commencements this weekend, hurting a state looking for new residents. POULTNEY, Vt.-As Green Mountain College readied to close its doors after 185 years, students enjoyed one of their final spring days on the pastoral campus, with some carrying kale and cabbage from the school's organic farm and others preparing for a class camping trip.

title: Hopes of Brexit Breakthrough Dashed as Bipartisan Talks Collapse
summary: The decision means the U.K.'s path out of the EU remains unclear. LONDON-The U.K.'s main opposition Labour Party on Friday pulled the plug on Brexit talks with the government, dashing hopes for a formal bipartisan solution to break the logjam in Parliament over the terms of Britain's withdrawal from the European Union.

title: Google May Know You Better Than You Know Yourself
summary: The company's move to monetize its Discover feed could be a game-changer. First, there was Google search, a blank canvas you used to find exactly what you already knew you wanted. Today, Google is serving users pages of goods before they can even think to look for them.

title: Baltimore Fights to Keep the Preakness
summary: The second leg of the Triple Crown has been run at Pimlico for more than a century, but the organizers of the race are positioning to move the race to Laurel Park. Baltimore

title: China Steel Boom, Supply Woes Push Iron-Ore Price to Five-Year High
summary: The benchmark price for cargoes of iron ore sold into northern China is up 38% this year. The price of iron ore surged to a five-year high, buoyed by mine closures in Brazil and unexpectedly strong demand for steel in China.

title: Japan's Banks Are About to Get Even Feebler
summary: However the Bank of Japan responds, lenders will be hit by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's proposed tax increase. Japan's banks are the weak link in its economic framework. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's insistence on following through with a tax increase could make them weaker still.

title: When to Save for Retirement in a Roth 401(k)
summary: Many workers now have the opportunity to contribute to a Roth plan alongside a traditional 401(k). But lots of people who would benefit from picking that option aren't doing so.. Amanda Bennette works hard at her finances.

title: Factory Workers Become Coders as Companies Automate
summary: Employees who show aptitude are gaining new skills, helping businesses make better-quality products and bringing in more revenue. As automation changes the way factories operate, some U.S. companies are training workers in programming and robotics, letting machinists get a taste of coding.

title: 'China's Google' Posts First Loss Since 2005
summary: Baidu says challenges include a broader slowdown in the Chinese economy and tighter internet regulation. BEIJING-Chinese search-engine giant Baidu Inc. reported its first quarterly loss since going public in 2005 and warned that the cause-weak advertising-is likely to linger due to China's slowing economy.

title: China's Search Giant Hasn't Found the Answer for Growth Yet
summary: Baidu needs to make its core search business work. China's largest search engine continues its search for growth.

title: Markets Create Their Own Reality
summary: The market's reaction is a bigger danger to the economy than the direct effect of tariffs. Stock markets are often accused of living in an alternate reality, but to analyze the trade war with China you have to accept the truth: Stock markets make their own reality.

title: SAT to Give Students 'Adversity Score' to Capture Social and Economic Background
summary: New score comes as college admissions decisions are under scrutiny. The College Board plans to assign an adversity score to every student who takes the SAT to try to capture their social and economic background, jumping into the debate raging over race and class in college admissions.

title: U.S. Sanctions Russians, Chechens Over Whistleblowers' Deaths
summary: Move is likely to further escalate tensions between U.S. and Vladimir Putin's government in Moscow. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration, in an action that will likely further escalate tensions between the U.S. and Russia, on Thursday imposed sanctions on Russian and Chechen officials linked to the deaths of two whistleblowers critical of Russian President Vladimir Putin's government.

title: Silicon Valley Will Feel Sting of Export Restrictions Against Huawei
summary: Commerce Department limits on Huawei's access to U.S. chips could affect sales of tech giants including Qualcomm, Broadcom, Intel and Oracle. A U.S. clampdown on exports to Huawei Technologies Co. threatens to disrupt the Chinese company's access to critical suppliers across its businesses, from smartphones to 5G equipment-and Silicon Valley could share in the pain.

title: Boeing Faces More FAA Requests as It Completes 737 MAX Fix
summary: Federal regulators seek more information before the troubled jets can return to passenger service. Boeing Co. has completed a software fix for its 737 MAX jets but faces requests for additional information from U.S. regulators, another hurdle in returning the troubled aircraft to passenger service, the company said on Thursday.

title: U.S. Reduces Special Tariff on Turkish Steel
summary: The duty is cut to 25%; Trump administration cited lower imports, improvements in U.S. steel industry. The Trump administration trimmed special tariffs on steel imports from Turkey to 25%, the White House said Thursday, after having raised the duty to 50% last year.
